summary: This is an internal DOJ email from July 2020 summarizing a call about the collection and review of documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein case from the Southern District of Florida (SDFL). It details the scope of collected materials (emails, hard copies, FBI holdings), notes significant gaps in former US Attorney Alex Acosta's emails from a critical period, and reveals that Ghislaine Maxwell was not a focus of the original SDFL investigation despite being a captioned subject.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Former US Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: Former US Attorney whose email records from May-November 2007 have a critical gap. His communications and those of his staff were collected and reviewed as part of the document collection effort.

events.title: Maxwell Named Captioned Subject in SDFL Case
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was formally listed as a captioned subject in the FBI's Epstein case in the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Epstein Case Received by SDFL
events.description: The Jeffrey Epstein case was received by the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Epstein Case Opened in SDFL
events.description: The Jeffrey Epstein case was formally opened in the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Acosta and Staff Briefed on Epstein Case
events.description: US Attorney Alex Acosta and his staff were briefed on the Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: Critical Gap in Acosta's Emails
events.description: A critical period for which all of Alex Acosta's sent emails failed to be retained due to a change in the DOJ's email retention system.

events.title: Epstein Completes Sentence
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed his state sentence related to the SDFL case.

events.title: Anticipated OPR Report Release
events.description: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) report on the Epstein matter was anticipated to be publicly released in late summer 2020.

locations: West Palm Beach Resident Agency (West Palm RA)
keyFacts: A massive document collection effort was undertaken, covering hundreds of thousands of emails from SDFL and FBI holdings, including emails from key individuals like Alex Acosta and his staff.

There is a critical, insurmountable gap in former US Attorney Alex Acosta's sent emails from May to November 2007, a key period in the Epstein case, due to a change in the DOJ's email retention system.

Despite being a formally captioned subject in the FBI's SDFL case as of December 2, 2006, Ghislaine Maxwell's name did not appear in any reviewed documents or emails, and she was not addressed in the prosecution memo supporting Epstein's indictment.

The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) was in the final stages of its report on the Epstein matter, with a draft expected within a week and a public release anticipated for August 2020.
The document collection included a notorious "one-sided email" made public in CVRA litigation, which involved defense counsel communications that were redacted when released.
